title: Ripple Effect: Medford Police upgrade patrol cameras as vehicle thefts spike - KTVL
content:
Medford City Council recently approved a five-year $370,000 contract with that will outfit all 35 Medford Police patrol vehicles with new cameras.

Medford Police say the purpose of the upgrades is to give officers better tools to help locate vehicles associated with crimes. One of the biggest tools it’s adding to all of its patrol vehicles is Automatic License Plate Recognition (ALPR).

“It’s really going to be a great tool. They’re excited about it, we’re all excited about it,” Medford Police Patrol Lt. Rebecca Pietila said. “Because that ability to capture vehicles of interest is going to be exponentially increased.”

According to Axon’s website, two ALPR cameras on top of each patrol car can spot license plates of interest up to 50 feet away if they’re visible to the naked eye and alert officers immediately.



ALPR works by recognizing license plate numbers associated with crimes. Once a vehicle’s license plate is entered into MPD’s system, the new Axon readers can scan three lanes of traffic to locate it.



With these cameras, the officers are going to get an automatic alert that they’ve passed by this vehicle, and then a photo of that vehicle so we can take action right away,” Pietila said. “Whereas if a police officer was just driving down the road, they may or may not see that car and recognize it to be stolen and/or a suspect vehicle.”

She said this new contract will add Axon’s ALPR system to 26 more patrol vehicles and upgrade the nine MPD patrol vehicles that already have a different system. The , which is the full package MPD has purchased, will also give each vehicle a new dashcam and a wider-angle camera in the back seat to watch a suspect’s activity from head to toe.

These additions come at a time when vehicle thefts have dramatically increased in Medford, Pietila said.

Up until 10 years ago, Pietila says Medford had about 100 to 200 vehicle thefts per year.

Fast forward to 2021 and Medford had 252 vehicle thefts. In 2022, that number was 392, a 55.5% increase in vehicle thefts from the year before.

Medford City Councilor Kevin Stine says the rise in vehicle thefts was one of the reasons it was an immediate and unanimous yes vote for city councilors to approve the new camera upgrades last month. Stine said it was also a quick approval because they have seen the success of the nine ALPR systems they already have on MPD vehicles.



News10 asked Stine what makes him say the ALPR units have been successful when vehicle thefts have dramatically increased.

I think it just has to do with crime. Even if you have a way to catch the criminals easier, it might not deter someone,” Stine said. “Generally, it seems like the type of person to commit a crime is not really thinking about the consequences or their likelihood of getting caught. There are just maybe different societal issues on why people would be more willing to steal cars.”

Stine said the councilors agreed these camera upgrades are a smart way to use taxpayer money.

“Everything that you want to do is going to come at a cost. But when you look at, I think this is roughly $75,000 per year to outfit all of the police cars with cameras,” Stine said. “For the benefits, that seems like a small price to pay. We know it’s a successful program, and that having the technology on all police cars is a good thing for the city.”

The proposal was presented by and approved by the city council. Lieutenant Pietila said this new contract will save taxpayers money over their current system because MPD is using just one company for all its cameras instead of the two they currently pay.

“Essentially there’s a cost associated with Axon, which is a company that we work with and they provide tools for us,” Pietila said. “And then ALPR [the old system] is a different company. So the cost of those two current items is more than the revamping going to this entire new system.”

News10 sent an email to Pietila and Medford City spokesperson Kristina Wilson to find out how much taxpayer money the new contract will save, but has not received a response. Once News10 receives a response, this article will be updated with that information.



Not only with these upgrades bring MPD new cameras, but they will also bring new features.

“Now, we’ve got live streaming capabilities. So our command staff can live stream incidents that are happening in front of police cars or within police cars,” Pietila said. “So we have that ability, which we haven’t had before. Additionally, we have really great GPS abilities with these cameras.”

Pietila explained how this new live-streaming ability to access officers’ car cameras and body cameras in real time could be a game-changer.



“Our ability to be outside of a critical incident and be able to view what’s going on is a really, really great tool and resource for us,” she said. “Because if we’re removed as an incident commander, we can look at what’s going on and offer feedback or come up with a plan, a tactical plan, while watching what’s happening right in front of our eyes.”

City councilor Stine said he’s excited to see the impact these new upgrades will have on locating vehicles associated with crimes and making live plans to bring them to justice.

He said these tools will be helpful even though they might not be something residents often think about.

People might not think about it until you need it, then you’re happy that MPD has the ability to retrieve your car if it’s stolen,” Stine said. “This might not matter to you until those types of negative things occur.”

News10 asked Stine about the potential negative aspects of this new technology coming to MPD.

“It’s just the concern about collecting data. There is the thought, ‘is this data going to go in the wrong hands? Who has access to it?' Things like that,’” Stine said. “So that’s one of the things I heard, which I understand. But this is not something where anyone in the police force can just go and mine through data and find things that are unrelated to police work. That’s just not available. This is solely for the criminal activity portion of what the capabilities are.”

Stine and Pietila both said they’re not exactly sure when all 35 cars will have the cameras from the Axon Fleet 3 package because of the time it takes to install them. The department’s new contract with Axon starts in July, so the cameras and features should be installed sometime this year.
